elements.text:
I honestly think that if you've got what it takes you can start from anywhere and just work until it works. Even if you start with something simple and apparently useless like WOM you can just push and push until you either get to the point where it works or you learn enough to move your understanding on.

If WOM was the only idea you had what could you do with it? Could you think of different ways to think about it or compose it? Or imagine all you had was WOM and you couldn't see anything else about the market - could you find a way to price the whole market based on just that? What would that look like?

Grinding out any idea however shit is far more likely to bring home the bacon than flitting from one superficially investigated idea to another in the hope that you strike gold on something that other people somehow haven't noticed.

That said, I don't think ANYONE can do it, most people can't do it, even most smart and seemingly qualified people can't do it, even if they try really hard. Somehow there are just people who can do it and people who can't. It's not the cleverest or the best or the hardest workers who succeed at this, it's just the people who can do it. So don't grind too hard or too long, if this doesn't work there are plenty of better things to do.

text: <@UPMUFSGCR> In strategy research you have endless roads you can go down. How do you choose one? How far down that road do you go? You've spent over a month, hit a bunch of dead ends, is it time to call it quits? What will you learn upon failure (the most likely outcome) by going down that road? I've tried working with other people, this is what I've found to be the lacking skill.

elements.text: In strategy research you have endless roads you can go down. How do you choose one? How far down that road do you go? You've spent over a month, hit a bunch of dead ends, is it time to call it quits? What will you learn upon failure (the most likely outcome) by going down that road? I've tried working with other people, this is what I've found to be the lacking skill.

text: The thing is, you never quit. It took Edison 3000 attempts to create the first lighbulb, why should this be any different?

elements.text: The thing is, you never quit. It took Edison 3000 attempts to create the first lighbulb, why should this be any different?

text: It’s just hypothesis validation/nullification at its core, no? That’s what Edison did. Each idea came from experience (observations from what he had tried), but it was still scientific method.

elements.text: It’s
just hypothesis validation/nullification at its core, no?
That’s
what Edison did. Each idea came from experience (observations from what he had tried), but it was still scientific method.

text: Also, as an aside, Edison was a twat who stole more than he invented. Tesla is a better inspiration. Point still holds: scientific method is the best we have for iterating towards truth.

elements.text: Also, as an aside, Edison was a twat who stole more than he invented. Tesla is a better inspiration. Point still holds: scientific method is the best we have for iterating towards truth.

text: <@U012XF5CNPN> At it's simplest, yeah it's hypothesis validation/nullification. But in practice there's A LOT of intuition and marginal decision making. You'll rarely fully nullify a bad hypothesis, and most of your hypothesis will be bad ones.

elements.text: At it's simplest, yeah it's hypothesis validation/nullification. But in practice there's A LOT of intuition and marginal decision making. You'll rarely fully nullify a bad hypothesis, and most of your hypothesis will be bad ones.

text: Someone mentioned in-play greyhounds? Can't speak for the UK, but in Aus I am working on the IsolLynx timing system, that does accelerometer data at 400 times/second, and I have speed and to rail data 25 times/second which I have processed and "smoothed" so mostly accurate to about 2 cm. I do the data processing, putting it into a DB, creating an API, which is now used by the Australian State bodies. Lots more work to do (I'm now on it full time)

text:
<@UPMUFSGCR> I don't know what the magic ingredient is, but I observe that a higher than expected proportion of successful players don't fit what you might expect to be the mold  and that many people who you would think are very well placed to succeed don't make it work.

Perhaps there's no one particular thing that winners all share, some people are just brilliant, some  batter away until they get there, some are just devious. You need a bit of something though, and I don't think it's something they teach in University, whatever you study.

elements.text:
I don't know what the magic ingredient is, but I observe that a higher than expected proportion of successful players don't fit what you might expect to be the mold  and that many people who you would think are very well placed to succeed don't make it work.

Perhaps there's no one particular thing that winners all share, some people are just brilliant, some  batter away until they get there, some are just devious. You need a bit of something though, and I don't think it's something they teach in University, whatever you study.

text: PS, the reason I bothered logging on here is to do with live tennis scores (tagging <@UBS7QANF3>). We all know that the API is not great due to data rights, but the exchange in-play service in the main gives good scores and timely updates. But...there have been two tournaments in the last two weeks that don't have live scores: ATP Washington and ATP Kitzbuhel. I note the scores are on the Sportsbook site. So does anyone know what is going on? And secondly, the Sportsbook site uses GraphQL, so has anyone used it to get live scores?

text: Last thing: the original model I have actually does work, but with high variance. After 1.5 years there was not enough data to know. Now I have 4 years of data and it seems to be pretty consistent over 4 years. In terms of sizing we were a bit naive - due to the first 6 months all showing significant profits. Increased sizes made it a wild ride. So back to data collection, a full-time job as software development manager for a betting agency who started up in the US, and now doing the greyhounds stuff full-time, among other things

err oh! So I shall give you one of the params I am using, it is the ratio of the (available_back/available_lay), my logic behind this one is "against the crowd", so if this ratio is > 1.0 say, that indicates higher available_back, ie.more people are offering to "lay" thinking price is higher, so my logic is price is lower.....

text: Serious question now: when you went from 270K bank to 130K bank in the space of a week (fortnight?) were you honestly not tempted to pull the plug and take a deeper look at what was going on?
